"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We need to get to a point where we can sell a $35,000 car and where the full accountable COGS of the car is, let's say, on the order of $30,000. That would be our goal. That's what we're pushing very hard to achieve."

"summary_text": "The time to get the car from a factory to a customer was 30 days, down to 20 at the end of the quarter. Where do we see that flow through from a COGS perspective? Is that in automotive gross margin? Or is that in services and other at this point?Deepak AhujaTESLA, INC. FQ3 2018 EARNINGS CALL  OCT 24, 2018."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We see no fundamental issues on the production ramp. It's just a question of how quickly we can solve each issue. We feel very confident at being able to get to several hundred vehicles per week by the end of the year. The -- with respect to stationary storage, I mean, the -- that is, again, sort of a production limited thing."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We try to be proactive, so if we -- without -- well before we're sort of forced to do a recall, we proactively try to fix things in the cars that we think might, in the future, be issue. 97% of respondents said that their next car would be a Tesla. Frankly, this is the only question people should care about."

"summary_text": "Jeffrey B. Straubel: We definitely read the report and we're not terribly concerned about it. I mean, we are constantly agonizing about cell costs and pack costs. And we don't think anyone is on a path to be even close to us. If they are, I would be the first tocongratulate them."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: Right now, we're actually very, very happy with the quality of the drive units. We want drive units that just never wear out. That's our goal. So driving that's going out now are -- and for the last several months, have been excellent."

"summary_text": "A year ago, you guys had been targeting 28% to 30% gross margins by around this time. So what's the right way to think about gross margin over the next 18 months? Well, we -- our goal is to steadily improve gross margin, and hopefully exceed 30% on the S and X line."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: It's not as big a leap as it might seem from Q4 to Q3 because there's a whole weak missing from Q3. It's worth noting that 2015 -- in 2010, Tesla was delivering 500 cars per year. We now deliver 500 cars in just over 2 days."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We expect the similarly equipped Model X to be no more than $5,000 greater than the price of a Model S. He said that deliveries for the Model X initially are clearly a function of how many you can build, given your large backlog of orders."

"summary_text": "Our next question comes from the line of Colin Rusch with Oppenheimer. Colin, can you talk a little bit about the acceleration in the ramp of the Gigafactory? And when do you think, we might see cells coming out of the factory and into cars? And then, just in terms of the dynamics around leasing, are you seeing any real meaningful changes in overall lease take rates?"

"summary_text": "The next question comes from the line of Brian Johnson with Barclays. Brian, what's going to be different in terms of hitting that ramp-up on deliveries for Model S in 4Q vis-\u00e0-vis drawing down that inventory? And to clarify just the Model X pricing, is that based on range and features? Or is it just based onBattery size, the $5,000 difference?"

"summary_text": "Last quarter, we delivered more than 95,000 vehicles, which is a record for Tesla. Model 3 is once again the best-selling premium vehicle in the U.S., outselling all of its gas-powered counterparts combined. By the end of this year, we expect to be producing Model 3s in volume out of Gigafactory Shanghai."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We don't talk too much about like detailed price plans, but I mean if you're asking like what do I think the long-term demand for Model 3 is in Greater China region, I think it's about 5,000 a week. Musk: Our plan is to -- well, to source cars to sort of greater Europe area from Fremont, California, and until we have European Gigafactory operational."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: I think we'll -- demand in Q3 will exceed Q2. And then I think Q4 will be, I think, very strong. So we expect like quarter-over-quarter improvements. I think next year will be tough. Q1 and 4 will be good. Q2 will be not as bad but still tough."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: Long term, we are talking 25%, 30%. Not -- long term meaning like a \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0year. That 30% gross margin is, I think, quite likely. We continue to take significant costs out of the Model 3 in particular as well."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We are reconfiguring the floorspace in Fremont, and there's like quite a lot of factory space that'scurrently taken up with the S/X parts warehousing. And we don't really need that, so that's where we're putting the Model Y activity. Jerome Guillen: We're improving the material delivery for S and X just like we have done for Model 3."

"summary_text": "The regulatory credits composition is a mixture of these particular deals that are onetime. There's also some that are production-based over time. And then your final question was on does it make sense to sacrifice pricing to drive regulatory credit incertain markets? It might. But generally, we're selling cars in markets at the prices we think are appropriate."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We don't expect to be cell-constrained in China for the next year. Drew Baglino: That's what our plan looks like right now. Colin Rusch: How should we be thinking about sustainable volumes and pricing on those volumes? And can I have a follow-up question around Model S and Model X saturation?"

"\"summary_text\": \"Elon Musk: Over time an autonomous vehicle is going to be far, far safer than a person. The car has 8 cameras looking 360 degrees all the time. It's got a board radar, it's got 12 high-precision ultrasonic sonars. And over 10 tera ops of computing capability that never sleeps.\"",

"\"summary_text\": \"The conversion rates have continued to improve. On the solar side, one of the interesting things that we're seeing is we put a solar display in -- an energy display into our stores in North America. It's really working well together. And we're actually able to leverage our existing stores to generate even more sales per square foot.\"",

"summary_text": "Elon Musk, J.B. Straubel, Deepak Ahuja, Robin Ren, Jerome Guillen, Andrej Karpathy, Stuart Bowers, Pete Bannon, and other members of the Tesla team are on the call. During the call, we will discuss our business outlook and make forward-looking statements."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We're incredibly proud of the Tesla team for producing 7,000 Model 3, Model S and Model X vehicles in the last week of June. We expect to, in the absence of a force majeure or some very unexpected events, be able to achieve an average of 5,000 model 3s or above per week for Q3."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We booked a tremendous amount with Gigafactory 1. And we're confident that we can do the Gigaf factory in China for a lot less. J.B. Straubel: We found surprising number of ways to improve efficiency and speed anddensity as well."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: I think still, by and large, what we will be aiming for is steel frame buildings. The tent itself might be a little bit of a distraction from actually the focus of what's happening inside. It's taught us a lot of lessons on how to be capital efficient in the general assembly area. And after this call, I'm headed up back out to the body shop."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We're highly confident of being cash.flow positive and GAAP profitable in Q3 and Q4. Deepak Ahuja: It doesn't matter exactly where we are in the month of July. What really matters is over the quarter because it depends on deliveries, depends on production."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We're aiming for a million in 2020, but somewhere between 0.5 million and 1 million seems pretty likely. Shanghai will be important for that, he said. Musk: \"We are hoping to identify a Gigafactory location in Europe before the end of this year\""

"summary_text": "The first question is from Colin Langan of UBS. The question is about the increase in accounts payable and accrued liabilities. Is that just this thing with the ramp in production? And what are the key drivers that are actually going to get you to profitability in Q4 without ZEV credits?"

"summary_text": "A quarter ago, you were guiding to roughly 80,000 vehicles. A year and now 3 months later, we're down at 75,000. Can you just walk us through the factors that are impacting that lower shipment number, or delivery number, I should say. With nearly 40% increase in deliveries, can you guys break out the impact in gross margin to absorption?"

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We're very confident that a camera solution with 12 ultrasonics and a forward radar and the computing power that we now have on board is capable of taking us all the way to full autonomy. The blog that I wrote was very clear that radar is moving from a supplemental to also a primary sensor."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: R&D will continue to go up. But not like -- not in giant ways. Jason S. Wheeler: On the SG&A side, that's where we're really finding our operating leverage. Jonathan McNeill: CapEx was 25% year-over-year, and we bumped that up to 30% this quarter."

"summary_text": "Jason Wheeler: We're still generally on track as we stated with the Gigafactory schedule and production. There's equipment being installed and being commissioned as we speak. So we feel good about where that's at, and we feel that we're definitely on schedule for production for Model 3."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We already see a significantimprovement in safety with the semiautonomous features. The more time that goes by, the more miles we accumulate, the stronger the argument gets about the confidence interval. So I'm really quite optimistic about where things are and where they're headed on that front."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We've put out some very compelling loan products in the marketplace. We're always looking for ways where we can provide just compelling and useful financing programs for our consumers. And if we can use other folks' capital for that, great. If we use our capital for it, that's fine too."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: I think it's a bit of both, really. It's not Teslaversus Uber; it's the people versus Uber. This would be a significant offset on the cost of ownership of a car and then a revenuegenerator for Tesla as well."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: Production ramp tends to look like a -- is exponential or ultimately, it's an S-curve. Exponential goes to linear, then goes to log. It's very difficult to predict exactly where that beginning part of the exponential and the S curve fits in between quarter to quarter."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We don't need to go out and raise much equity. The -- there could be unexpected things that occur. There could be some global macroeconomic slowdown. And so there may be value in derisking the business. We're not ready to make that decision yet."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We're really focused on Gigafactory 1 and Model 3, spending very little time on facilities outside of Fremont, California and Sparks, Nevada. So it's really hard to say at this point except to say it's pretty obvious that long term, you want to have your production close to your consumption."

"summary_text": "All right. Thanks a lot, Chanel, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. And I'm showing no further questions on the phone lines at this time. Back to the page you came from. back to the site you were coming from. Back from the page."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk, J.B. Straubel, Deepak Ahuja and Jon McNeill will be on the call to discuss Tesla's third quarter results. During this call, we will discuss our business outlook and make forward-looking statements. These comments are based on our predictions and expectations as of today."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We continue to make significant progress each week. We see no primary problems withour supply chain or any of our production processes. There's 10,000 unique parts. We expect to achieve approximately 5,000 Model 3 vehicles per week by late Q1 2018."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: I was reallydepressed about 3 or 4 weeks ago when I realized that we were kind of in level 9. Then we got to level 8. Now I can see sort of a clear path to sunshine. The whole team's on it, we're on it. And we've got it covered."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: Model 3 is much easier to build than S or X because the system is designed as a very tightly automated system. Musk: The number of actual, what we call a pitch, which is a station for a robot to work on the car in general assembly, is about 1/4 of the typical industry average for number of stations."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: I think that we'll be able to achieve full autonomy with the current hardware. For customers that have signed up for full subject riding capability, we'll push that option. The -- if it does turn out that a computer upgrade is necessary in order to meet the regulatory requirements in that area, we will replace their computer."

"summary_text": "Deepak Ahuja: As we continue to ramp up Model 3, our cash flow of operations is going to increase or improve significantly over the next few quarters. We are managing our CapEx and OpEx growth to be in line with the growth of our fleet. So all those actions will come through in terms of helping us conserve cash."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: It's a bit too early to make the exact number. But I think, if you extrapolate from 5,000 units towards the end of Q1, we do want to hold off on giving CapEx until we are confident about cash flow on Model 3."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We're talking about a rate ofgrowth faster than the Model T, which is the fastest in history. So these are nutty growth rates. Next year even with 5,000, it'll be like crazy compared to this year. So our growth rate continues to be extraordinary."

"summary_text": "The next question comes from Colin Rusch from Oppenheimer. Could you talk about the percentage of sales that are coming from these loaners to the fleet vehicles? And then, if you could talk a little bit about why you felt that it was necessary to add value to the Model S and Model X while lowering price."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We are -- we do expect the solar demand to rebound as we move solar sales into all of our stores. The Solar Roof stuff, we expect, is going to be at -- or well, we're confident it's going to haveextremely high demand. And we continue to install pilot engineering, early customer homes."

"summary_text": "Automotive gross margin, excluding ZEV credits, grew from 20.1% in Q1 to 21.2% inQ2. We ended up with $3.25billion on the balance sheet at the end of the quarter. We've got $678 million drawn on our asset-backed line. We're focused on volumetric efficiency."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: I don't think there's a strong park rationale to combine SpaceX and Tesla, whereas there is for Tesla and SolarCity. There's a little cooperation that happens between the companies but it's not enough that would justify merging them into 1 entity. And can you also give us update us on your -- on Tesla's proprietary mapping initiatives?"

"summary_text": "Our next question comes from the line of Brian Johnson of Barclays. Brian, can you walk us between the 373,000 Model S preorders and the $375 million in deposits in the quarter? And what do the amendments to the credit agreement for SolarCity kind of do to your ability to borrow against that for this captive financing?"

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: There's no question Tesla's going to do integrated inverter. Most people don't even know what an inverter is. What is an -- they've never heard of this thing. Jason S. Wheeler: Our goal is to make them seamless and easy for people to use."

"summary_text": "Jonathan McNeill: We had year-over-year growth in Model S demand and we also -- we had some very healthy growth in the markets where we had cars in stores. So we had double-digit growth in both North America and China, and that growth has continued into the third quarter. Elon Musk: We're right around 2,000 vehicles a week."

"summary_text": "The quality, I think, has improved quite dramatically, particularly with respect to X. We had a lot of challenges in the production ramp. That's always the most difficult time when you're going from 0 to 1,000 cars a week. So I actually feel pretty good about warranty reserves actually declining over time as a result of that."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: Things are -- things feel really quite stable. We're kind of in the mode of continuous improvement, but no fundamental issues, so it's -- I feel like the machine that's making X and S is actually functioning quite well right now. The focus really is on Model 3, followed by full autonomy as probably the top 2 priorities."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: Because people are optioning up the 60, it actually ends up being decent. I mean, maybe it's sort of like 15% to 20% gross margin, whereas say, something like if. somebody orders the performance dual motor, that might actually be more like a 30%, 35% gross. margin. Jason S. Wheeler: We expect where we're at today, we'll see another 2 to 3 points of expansion between now and the end of the year."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: I'm cautiously optimistic that we'll actually meet those numbers by the end of the year. The 60s may have some -- one other impact on gross margin. Elon, as you transition to an in-house autopilot, would you consider, in order to help build public support and confidence, about releasing regular reports similar to like Google does on what the technology is doing?"

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We were in production hell for the first 6 months of this year. And then we just managed to sort of climb out of hell or -- in like basically part way through June and now we're -- the production line is humming. And our suppliers mostly have their sh*t together. There's a few that don't."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: There's nothing even remotely close to demand constraints on the Tesla Energy side. The Model 3, I mean, the internal name for the designing machine that makes the machine is the -- what we call the alien dreadnought. At the point at which the factory looks like an alien Dreadnought, you know, it's like what the hell is that?"

"summary_text": "With the residual value guarantee going away, what happens to the accounting for revenues? Do you kind of get to something more close to what we see in other OEM financials and maybe just have the portion that's direct lease be accounted for as well? And what would be the timing of changes assuming they do have them?Jason S. Wheeler: The answer to timing, it changes right away."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: Full autonomy is it's really a software limitation. The hardware is -- I mean, the hardware exists to create full autonomy. It's really about developing advanced narrow AI for the car to operate on. So increasingly sophisticated neuro maps that can operate in reasonably sized computers in the car; that's our focus."

"summary_text": "The next question comes from Tyler Frank of Robert Baird. Tyler, can you discuss when you expect to be profitable on a non-GAAP basis? And then #2, you had mentioned on the last call that the Gigafactory may actually have the ability to produce about 3 times of your original estimate. Will that entail significant CapEx in the future or are you preparing that foundation right now to reach over 100 gigawatt hours?"

"summary_text": "Sure thing. Sure thing. I'll get back to you in a few minutes. I'm sorry. I just wanted to make sure you were OK. I love you. I really, really do. I will. I won't be offended if you're not."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: We expect to see a significant ramp in Q4 for the X and have something that may be as much as 2x other quarters. There are huge advanced orders for the Model X, and we see a steady climb in demand for the S. The development took a lot longer than we originally anticipated."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: We'll see demand for stationary storage as measured in sort of megawatt hours or gigawatts hours to be approximately double that of the car. That's our best guess for long-term demand yet. The high-energy pack is more like around the -- maybe depending on how it's used, anywhere from 1,000 to 1,500 cycles. And the daily cycler one, I mean, we're expected to be able to daily cycle for something on the order of 15 years."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: It is tricky, as companies grow, to maintain a consistent culture. I think we're doing okay.Jeffrey B. Straubel: Having a general mix of people that have been here for a very long time and have seen the company when it was even much smaller."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: The 85D has been a big hit in Europe. We're establishing a big casting foundry and machining facility in Fremont. And yes, that's what's happening in Lathrop primarily. The factory size has increased almost 40%. And what is happening there?"

"summary_text": "I was a little surprised by the sequential drop in ZEV gross margins. I think you guys had obviously very good gross margins this quarter relative to some of the headwinds that you were facing. And I guess I was surprised to see that x ZEV, they go from 26 to 25."

During this call, we will discuss our business outlook and make forward-looking statements. These comments are based on our predictions and expectations as of today."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: Over time an autonomous vehicle is going to be far, far safer than a person. The car has 8 cameras looking 360 degrees all the time. It's got a board radar, it's got 12 high-precision ultrasonic sonars. And over 10 tera ops of computing capability that never sleeps."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: The number of Superchargers will, in fact, triple between now and the end of next year. We're confident that, that will address the Supercharging needs of S, X and 3. We'll also be experimenting with our first sort of, I don't recall, megaSupercharger location."

"summary_text": "The pace of OpEx through second half, you guided was flat. With the Model 3 going out, are youbasically saying you have the operating infrastructure to handle that, but then does that ramp in 2018? And similarly for CapEx to go from 30 Model 3s up to the exit rate, you're talking $2 billion. How do we think about, a, that run rate and given how do we tie it to your exponential ramp? And b, what does that say about CapEx going into 2018?"

"summary_text": "The conversion rates have continued to improve. On the solar side, one of the interesting things that we're seeing is we put a solar display in -- an energy display into our stores in North America. It's really working well together. And we're actually able to leverage our existing stores to generate even more sales per square foot."

"summary_text": "Elon Musk: I'd like to announce that our CFO, Jason Wheeler, has decided to leave Tesla \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0in April. Jason will be replaced by Deepak Ahuja, who was Tesla's first CFO and worked for the company for more than 7 years before stepping away in 2015."

"summary_text": "Elon R. Musk: The Model 3 is designed -- is really designed for manufacturing. It's considerably a simpler car than the S or the X. We simplified the wiring system considerably. The Gigafactory's a huge asset for powertrain, power electronics, chargers and a few other asset."

"summary_text": "The next question comes from the line of Joseph Spak with RBC Capital Markets. Joseph, I guess, relates to the delivery guidance which I know you limited to the first half. Is there the -- and the launch of the Model 3, is there the potential for disruption to S and X? Is that also one of the factors why you're sort of -- decided to sort ofguide the way you did?"
